Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Whole Ecosystem Experiments on Early Warnings for Regime Shifts to Cyanobacteria in Lakes
Award.AbstractNarration:
While nature often changes slowly, sometimes large changes occur fast. Fisheries collapse, rangelands decline, and invasive species expand rapidly often with high costs to human society. Big changes in ecological systems are difficult to forecast, but recent theoretical studies and experiments indicate that they are preceded by early warnings. These early warnings are like economic indicators and can be detected in environmental variables that can be measured frequently. In principle when early warning indicators are detected, actions can either avert unwanted changes, like responding to a check engine light in a car, or help minimize risk, like responding to a tornado siren. This project will test the potential to avoid unwanted changes in lakes by detecting early warning signals. Several lakes will be experimentally fertilized with nutrients to create the potential for massive growths of algae. Early warning signals will be detected by continuously monitoring the lakes with modern electronic sensors. In a further experiment, the researchers will respond to signals that indicate impending changes and stop the nutrient additions to one lake in an attempt to avoid algae proliferating to nuisance levels. Treatments to the other lakes will continue so that all possible responses are included.

This project will determine if methods for detecting early warnings signals can be developed. The findings from this study will be extended to a network of researchers who have established continuous measurement systems on lakes throughout the world. If successful, the results should be widely applicable for the management of a range of natural systems, not only lakes. The project will train graduate and undergraduate students and contribute to teaching materials for courses at universities in Virginia and Wisconsin, as well as advanced special topics courses at the Cary Institute of Ecosystem Studies in New York.

PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT:  DEB 1144683

Collaborative Research: Whole Ecosystem Experiments on Early Warnings for Regime Shifts to Cyanobacteria in Lakes

 

Abrupt changes in ecosystems, such as forest dieback, conversion of rangelands to desert, collapse of fisheries, or harmful algal blooms in water supplies, are difficult to predict yet have substantial impact on human health and livelihoods. Harmful blooms of toxic cyanobacteria are becoming more common in U.S. lakes and reservoirs. When they occur, these blooms interfere with use of lakes and reservoirs for drinking, watering livestock, boating, fishing, and swimming.

 

Recent advances in ecological theory suggests that abrupt changes, including harmful algal blooms, may be detected in advance. Advance detection requires monitoring of ecosystems with high-frequency sensors and computation of certain time series statistics, called resilience indicators. When resilience indicators exceed specified thresholds, the risk of abrupt change is especially high. This theory is well developed using mathematical and computer models, but few relevant tests have been performed under field conditions in real ecosystems.

 

We tested this theory by gradually adding nutrients (phosphorus and nitrogen) to lakes in order to induce harmful algal blooms. Algal pigments and chemical variables related to algal production were measured every five minutes by automated sensors in enriched lakes and an unenriched reference lake. Data were downloaded wirelessly each day for computation of resilience indicators. Two lakes were enriched for three years each, and the unenriched reference lake was monitored in the same three years.

 

In five of the six enrichment experiments (two lakes X 3 years per lake) harmful algal blooms occurred. All five blooms were correctly forecasted by at least one resilience indicator. No blooms occurred in the reference lake, and resilience indicators never exceeded their thresholds.  An event in which a resilience indicator exceeds its threshold is called an alarm. The number of alarms increased with magnitude of the bloom. Larger blooms were forecast by more alarms. Alarms occurred between one and 61 days prior to the bloom. In lake management, these early warnings may have come soon enough for managers to take preventive action, such as treating a bloom with algaecides, diverting intakes for water supplies, or diverting nutrient inputs.

 

In 2015, we halted nutrient inputs to one enriched lake when a pre-defined set of alarms occurred. This intervention prevented the bloom. Enrichment continued in the other enriched lake, leading to an algal bloom. This experiment showed that rapid intervention following alarms could prevent harmful algal blooms.

 

In summary, this project showed that resilience indicators successfully forecast harmful algal blooms. These forecasts have sufficient lead time that managers could potentially respond in time to avert the blooms. In one experiment, intervention triggered by resilience indicators successfully prevented a bloom. Thus the experiments corroborate ecological theory and provide a means of averting harmful algal blooms that may be useful in practice. Nonetheless, the safest way to avoid harmful algal blooms is to limit nutrient enrichment of lakes and reservoirs.
